1. The fuel price at the destination aerodrome is higher than that at the departure
2. The fuel price at the departure aerodrome is higher than that at the destination
3. The fuel price ratio, departure to destination, is greater than 1
4. There is no fuel available at the destination aerodrome.

A two-engine aircraft has three fuel tanks. At the time of take-off, its centre tank contains 650 kg of fuel, its left and right wing tanks contain 250 kg of fuel each. A pump from the centre tank is continuously transferring fuel to the wing tanks at 150 kg/h.
On its flight from A to B, the fuel flow is 170 kg/h. 35 minutes into the flight, the centre fuel tank pump fails. From the point of the failure, how long can the aircraft fly?

An aircraft with wing and centre tanks is flying from A to B, its fuel consumption is 133 kg/h.  Fuel is continuously being transferred from centre tank to the wing tanks. At some point along the route, the centre tank contains 500 kg of fuel, each wing tank contains 250 kg. When the centre tank pump fails, what is the remaining endurance?

Refer to the image
During a flight, a fault message appears stating that the valves allowing fuel to be transferred from the left outer wing tank to the left inner wing tank are stuck in the closed position. These valves can NOT be opened manually. Given the following information, determine the fuel available for the remainder of the flight.
Left and right inner tanks: 3000 kg each
Left and right outer tanks: full
Centre tank: empty
All other technical aspects of the fuel system operate normally.
Do NOT consider fuel imbalance restrictions for this scenario.

Refer to figure. 
 During a flight, a fault message appears stating that the valves allowing fuel to be transferred from the left outer wing tank to the left inner wing tank are stuck in the closed position. These valves can NOT be opened manually. Given the following information, determine the fuel available for the remainder of the flight.Left and right inner tanks: 3000 kg each 
 Left and right outer tanks: full 
 Centre tank: empty 
 All other technical aspects of the fuel system operate normally. 
 Do NOT consider fuel imbalance restrictions for this scenario.

Refer to figure.  
  The engines always feed from each individual inner tank (left engine from left tank and right engine From right tank).When the inner tanks have 4000 kg fuel in them the trim tack transfer all it's content evenly between the two inner tanks.When the inner tanks have less than 3500 kg the outer tanks transfer all their content into their respective inner tank via transfer valves.During flight when the fuel quantity reach 12730 kg the left hand transfer valve between the left outer and inner tanks fail to open. What is the remaining endurance for the right engine if the fuel flow is 5420 kg/h?

The engines always feed from each individual inner tank (left engine from left tank and right engine From right tank).
 When the inner tanks have 4000 kg fuel in them the trim tack transfer all it's content evenly between the two inner tanks.
 When the inner tanks have less than 3500 kg the outer tanks transfer all their content into their respective inner tank via transfer valves.
 During flight when the fuel quantity reach 12730 kg the left hand transfer valve between the left outer and inner tanks fail to open. What is the remaining endurance for the right engine if the fuel flow is 5420 kg/h?

The cross feed valve failed and fuel can not be transferred from the left outer tank to the left inner tank. It can not be opened manually either.  At the time the valve failed, the center tank is empty, the inner tanks have 3 000 kg of fuel each and the outer tanks are full.
How much fuel is available for the remainder of the flight? Fuel must pass through the inner tank to the engine.
 

-    Maximum fuel capacity per tank
  </tr>
  <tr> Outer tank: 691 kg
  </tr>
  <tr> Inner tank: 5 000 kg 
  </tr>
  <tr> Center tank: 7 500 kg

The engines always feed from each individual inner tank (left engine from left tank and right engine from right tank). 
The trim tank transfer all content to the inner tanks when the inner tanks have less than 4000kg.
The outer tanks transfer all content to the inner tanks when the inner tanks have less than 3500 kg.
The fuel state of the aeroplane is as follows: 

Trim tank: Full.
 Outer tanks: Full.
During the flight, the trim tank transfer pump fail when the total fuel on board is 18620 kg. What is the 
Remaining endurance if the aeroplane fuel consumption is 96 kg/min?

Refer to figure 033-138.
An aeroplane is using its fuel according to the following rules: Every engine always feeds from the inner tank on their respective side. An aft trim tank transfers all content to the inner tanks when these have less than 4 000 kg. The outer tanks transfer all content to the inner tanks when the inner tanks have less than 3 500 kg.
Trim tank and outer tanks of the aeroplane are full. During the flight, the trim tank transfer pump fails when total fuel on board is 18 590 kg. What is the remaining endurance, assuming a fuel consumption of 95 kg/min?

Refer to the Annex. The aeroplane uses fuel in the following order: Each engine feeds from the inner tank of the wing (Left engine feeds from Left Inner Tank; Right Engine from Right Inner Tank) When the inner tanks have 4000 Kg then the Trim Tank tranfers all its contents equally to the Inner Tanks. When the Inner Tanks have 3500 Kg then the Outer tanks tranfer their contents to the Inner Tanksvia Transfer Valves. Fuel state: Outer Tanks FULL Trim Tank FULL During the flight the Trim Tank transfer pump fails when the total fuel on board is 18620 Kg What is the Aeroplane's Total Endurance if the fuel consumption is 96 Kg /Min
